clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_facts: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_facts: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_facts: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is home to a famous clock tower called Big Ben.
Known for its red double-decker buses and black cabs.
fun_facts: London has over 170 museums, many of which are free to enter!
The London Underground is the oldest metro system in the world, opening in 1863.
trivia: The city has more than 8 million residents, making it one of the most populous cities in Europe.
London Bridge is not the famous tower bridge—it’s a common misconception!

clues: This city is home to a famous opera house with a unique sail-like design.
Known for its stunning harbor and iconic bridge.
fun_facts: The Sydney Opera House was designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon and took 14 years to build.
Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its arch-based design.
trivia: Sydney is the largest city in Australia but not the capital—that’s Canberra!
The city hosted the 2000 Summer Olympics, one of the most successful games in history.

clues: This city is home to an ancient amphitheater called the Colosseum.
Known as the 'Eternal City' and the capital of the Roman Empire.
fun_facts: Rome has a museum dedicated entirely to pasta—it’s called the Museo della Pasta!
The city has more than 900 churches, including the famous St. Peter’s Basilica.
trivia: Rome is built on seven hills, which are still a defining feature of the city today.
The Trevi Fountain collects over €1 million in coins each year, which is donated to charity.

clues: This city is home to the Great Pyramid of Giza, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
Known as the 'City of a Thousand Minarets' due to its many mosques.
fun_facts: Cairo is the largest city in Africa and the Middle East.
The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years.
trivia: Cairo’s metro system is one of only two in Africa (the other is in Algiers).
The city is located near the Nile River, the longest river in the world.

clues: This city is famous for its giant statue of Christ the Redeemer overlooking the city.
Known for its annual Carnival festival and samba parades.
fun_facts: Rio de Janeiro means 'River of January' in Portuguese, named by explorers who thought the bay was a river.
The Christ the Redeemer statue is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
trivia: Rio is home to the world-famous Copacabana and Ipanema beaches.
The city hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics, the first time the games were held in South America.

clues: This city is known for its iconic Brandenburg Gate and remnants of the Berlin Wall.
A hub for techno music and modern art.
fun_facts: Berlin has more bridges than Venice—over 1,700 in total!
The Berlin Wall was 96 miles long and divided the city for 28 years.
trivia: Berlin is nine times larger than Paris in terms of area.
The city has over 180 museums, including the famous Museum Island.

clues: This city is home to the colorful domes of St. Basil’s Cathedral.
Known for its Red Square and the Kremlin.
fun_facts: Moscow has the largest number of billionaires in the world, surpassing New York City.
The Moscow Metro is one of the most beautiful subway systems, with chandeliers and mosaics.
trivia: Moscow is the coldest megacity in the world, with temperatures dropping to -30°C in winter.
The city’s name comes from the Moskva River, which flows through it.

clues: This city is known for its ornate temples and bustling street markets.
Home to the famous Wat Arun and Grand Palace.
fun_facts: Bangkok’s full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world, with 169 characters!
The city has over 400 Buddhist temples.
trivia: Bangkok is one of the most visited cities in the world, attracting over 22 million tourists annually.
The city’s floating markets are a unique cultural experience.

clues: This city is home to the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khalifa.
Known for its luxury shopping, ultramodern architecture, and vibrant nightlife.
fun_facts: Dubai has a police force that uses supercars like Lamborghinis and Ferraris!
The city has an indoor ski resort, Ski Dubai, in the middle of the desert.
trivia: Dubai’s Palm Jumeirah is an artificial archipelago shaped like a palm tree.
The city imports sand for construction because its desert sand is too fine for building.

clues: This city is known for its iconic Table Mountain and stunning coastal scenery.
A gateway to the Cape of Good Hope and the famous Robben Island.
fun_facts: Table Mountain is one of the oldest mountains in the world, estimated to be over 260 million years old.
Cape Town is home to the only street in the world to have two Nobel Prize winners living on it: Vilakazi Street.
trivia: The city has a penguin colony at Boulders Beach.
Cape Town’s Kirstenbosch Botanical Garden is one of the most beautiful in the world.

clues: This city is famous for its unique architecture by Antoni Gaudí, including the Sagrada Família.
Known for its vibrant culture, beaches, and football team FC Barcelona.
fun_facts: The Sagrada Família has been under construction for over 140 years and is still not finished!
Barcelona’s Park Güell was originally intended to be a housing estate but is now a public park.
trivia: The city hosted the 1992 Summer Olympics, which transformed its waterfront.
Barcelona has 12 abandoned metro stations, some of which are used for film sets.

clues: This city-state is known for its futuristic skyline and the iconic Marina Bay Sands.
Famous for its strict laws and cleanliness.
fun_facts: Singapore has a building called the ‘Interlace’ that looks like a stack of Jenga blocks!
The city has a night safari, the first of its kind in the world.
trivia: Singapore is one of only three city-states in the world (the others are Monaco and Vatican City).
Chewing gum is banned in Singapore, except for medicinal purposes.

clues: This city straddles two continents, Europe and Asia, connected by the Bosphorus Bridge.
Known for its historic Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque.
fun_facts: Istanbul was the capital of three great empires: Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman.
The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world.
trivia: The city has over 3,000 mosques.
Istanbul’s Basilica Cistern is an ancient underground water reservoir supported by 336 columns.

clues: This city is known for its skyscrapers, Victoria Harbour, and bustling street markets.
Famous for its dim sum and vibrant nightlife.
fun_facts: Hong Kong has more skyscrapers than any other city in the world!
The city’s Star Ferry has been operating since 1888 and is one of the cheapest ways to cross Victoria Harbour.
trivia: Hong Kong has the highest number of Rolls-Royce cars per capita in the world.
The city’s airport, Chek Lap Kok, was built on an artificial island.

clues: This city is known for its imperial palaces, classical music, and coffeehouse culture.
Home to the famous Vienna State Opera and Schönbrunn Palace.
fun_facts: Vienna has been voted the most livable city in the world multiple times!
The city’s Ferris wheel, the Wiener Riesenrad, is one of the oldest in the world.
trivia: Vienna is home to the world’s oldest zoo, the Tiergarten Schönbrunn.
The city has over 1,500 coffeehouses, a tradition dating back to the 17th century.

clues: This city is home to the iconic CN Tower and a diverse multicultural population.
Known for its film festival and sports teams like the Toronto Raptors.
fun_facts: The CN Tower was the tallest freestanding structure in the world for 32 years!
Toronto has over 140 languages spoken, making it one of the most multicultural cities in the world.
trivia: The city’s PATH underground walkway is the largest underground shopping complex in the world.
Toronto’s Yonge Street is listed in the Guinness World Records as the longest street in the world.

clues: This city is known for its K-pop culture, historic palaces, and futuristic technology.
Home to the famous Gangnam District and N Seoul Tower.
fun_facts: Seoul has the fastest internet speeds in the world!
The city’s subway system is one of the most extensive, with over 300 stations.
trivia: Seoul has over 10 million residents, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
The city’s Gyeongbokgung Palace was built in 1395 and is a symbol of Korean history.

clues: This city is known for its canals, cycling culture, and historic Anne Frank House.
Famous for its tulips, windmills, and liberal attitudes.
fun_facts: Amsterdam has more bicycles than people!
The city’s canals are a UNESCO World Heritage Site and stretch over 100 kilometers.
trivia: Amsterdam’s Schiphol Airport is located 4 meters below sea level.
The city has over 1,200 bridges, earning it the nickname 'Venice of the North.'

clues: This city is known for its deep-dish pizza and towering skyscrapers.
Home to the Willis Tower and Millennium Park.
fun_facts: Chicago’s nickname, 'The Windy City,' actually refers to its politicians, not the weather.
The city’s Riverwalk is a popular spot for dining and entertainment.
trivia: Chicago’s O’Hare International Airport is one of the busiest in the world.
The city’s Navy Pier is one of the most visited attractions in the Midwest.

clues: This city is known for its Hollywood sign and entertainment industry.
Home to the famous Walk of Fame and Griffith Observatory.
fun_facts: Los Angeles has more museums per capita than any other city in the world.
The city’s original name was 'El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora la Reina de los Ángeles.'
trivia: Los Angeles is the only city in North America to have hosted the Summer Olympics twice.
The city’s traffic is so notorious that it has its own term: 'Carmageddon.'

clues: This city is known for its vibrant nightlife and Art Deco architecture.
Home to South Beach and the Everglades National Park.
fun_facts: Miami is the only major city in the US founded by a woman, Julia Tuttle.
The city’s Little Havana is a cultural hub for Cuban exiles.
trivia: Miami’s beaches are so popular that they attract over 14 million visitors annually.
The city’s PortMiami is known as the 'Cruise Capital of the World.'

clues: This city is known for its casinos, entertainment, and vibrant nightlife.
Home to the famous Las Vegas Strip and Fremont Street.
fun_facts: Las Vegas is the brightest city on Earth when viewed from space.
The city’s Hoover Dam is one of the largest dams in the world.
trivia: Las Vegas hosts over 22,000 conventions annually.
The city’s Bellagio Fountains are one of the most photographed attractions.

clues: This city is known for its historic monuments and political significance.
Home to the White House and the National Mall.
fun_facts: Washington, D.C. was designed by French architect Pierre L’Enfant.
The city’s Smithsonian Institution is the world’s largest museum complex.
trivia: Washington, D.C. has more statues and memorials than any other city in the US.
The city’s Cherry Blossom Festival attracts over 1.5 million visitors annually.

clues: This city is known for its historic sites and prestigious universities.
Home to the famous Freedom Trail and Fenway Park.
fun_facts: Boston’s subway system, the 'T,' is the oldest in the United States.
The city’s Boston Common is the oldest public park in the US.
trivia: Boston’s Harvard University is the oldest institution of higher education in the US.
The city’s annual Boston Marathon is the world’s oldest annual marathon.

clues: This city is known for its coffee culture and the Space Needle.
Home to the famous Pike Place Market and tech giant Amazon.
fun_facts: Seattle’s Starbucks opened its first store in Pike Place Market in 1971.
The city’s Space Needle was built for the 1962 World’s Fair.
trivia: Seattle’s music scene gave birth to grunge music in the 1990s.
The city’s annual Seafair festival includes hydroplane races and air shows.

clues: This city is known for its historic landmarks and cheesesteaks.
Home to the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall.
fun_facts: Philadelphia’s City Hall was the tallest building in the world from 1901 to 1908.
The city’s LOVE Park is famous for its iconic LOVE sculpture.
trivia: Philadelphia’s University of Pennsylvania is home to the first medical school in the US.
The city’s annual Mummers Parade is one of the oldest folk festivals in the US.

clues: This city is known for its Southern hospitality and Coca-Cola.
Home to the Georgia Aquarium and Martin Luther King Jr. National Historic Site.
fun_facts: Atlanta’s Hartsfield-Jackson Airport is the busiest in the world.
The city’s Centennial Olympic Park was built for the 1996 Summer Olympics.
trivia: Atlanta’s CNN Center offers behind-the-scenes tours of the news network.
The city’s Fox Theatre is one of the most iconic entertainment venues in the US.

clues: This city is known for its cowboy culture and modern skyline.
Home to the famous Dealey Plaza and Reunion Tower.
fun_facts: Dallas’s Reunion Tower offers a 360-degree view of the city.
The city’s Southfork Ranch was the setting for the TV show 'Dallas.'
trivia: Dallas’s Arts District is the largest urban arts district in the US.
The city’s annual State Fair of Texas is one of the largest in the country.

clues: This city is known for its space exploration and diverse culture.
Home to NASA’s Johnson Space Center and the Houston Museum of Natural Science.
fun_facts: Houston’s Astrodome was the world’s first domed stadium.
The city’s nickname, 'Space City,' comes from its role in the space program.
trivia: Houston’s Museum District has 19 museums within a 1.5-mile radius.
The city’s annual Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo is the largest in the world.

clues: This city is known for its beaches and year-round sunny weather.
Home to the famous San Diego Zoo and Balboa Park.
fun_facts: San Diego’s Balboa Park is larger than New York’s Central Park.
The city’s San Diego Zoo is one of the largest and most famous in the world.
trivia: San Diego’s Gaslamp Quarter is a historic district with Victorian-era buildings.
The city’s annual Comic-Con is the largest pop culture event in the world.

clues: This city is known for its desert landscape and golf courses.
Home to the famous Camelback Mountain and Heard Museum.
fun_facts: Phoenix is the hottest major city in the US, with summer temperatures often exceeding 100°F.
The city’s name comes from the mythical bird that rises from its own ashes.
trivia: Phoenix’s South Mountain Park is one of the largest municipal parks in the US.
The city’s annual Phoenix Open is one of the most attended golf tournaments in the world.

clues: This city is known for its proximity to the Rocky Mountains and outdoor activities.
Home to the famous Red Rocks Amphitheatre and Denver Art Museum.
fun_facts: Denver’s elevation is exactly one mile above sea level, earning it the nickname 'The Mile High City.'
The city’s Red Rocks Amphitheatre is a natural outdoor concert venue.
trivia: Denver’s Union Station is a historic train station turned into a hub for dining and entertainment.
The city’s annual Great American Beer Festival is the largest in the US.

clues: This city is known for its theme parks and family-friendly attractions.
Home to Walt Disney World and Universal Studios Florida.
fun_facts: Orlando’s Walt Disney World is the most visited vacation resort in the world.
The city’s International Drive is a major tourist corridor with numerous attractions.
trivia: Orlando’s Lake Eola Park is home to a famous swan-shaped paddleboat.
The city’s annual Orlando International Fringe Festival is the oldest in the US.

clues: This city is known for its live music scene and tech industry.
Home to the famous South by Southwest (SXSW) festival and Texas State Capitol.
fun_facts: Austin’s slogan, 'Keep Austin Weird,' reflects its unique and eclectic culture.
The city’s Barton Springs Pool is a natural spring-fed pool that stays 68°F year-round.
trivia: Austin’s South by Southwest (SXSW) festival is one of the largest in the world.
The city’s annual Austin City Limits Music Festival attracts over 450,000 attendees.

clues: This city is known for its country music and vibrant nightlife.
Home to the Grand Ole Opry and the Country Music Hall of Fame.
fun_facts: Nashville’s nickname, 'Music City,' comes from its rich musical heritage.
The city’s Ryman Auditorium is known as the 'Mother Church of Country Music.'
trivia: Nashville’s Parthenon is a full-scale replica of the original in Athens, Greece.
The city’s annual CMA Fest is one of the largest country music festivals in the world.

clues: This city is known for its jazz music and Mardi Gras celebrations.
Home to the famous French Quarter and Bourbon Street.
fun_facts: New Orleans’ French Quarter is the oldest neighborhood in the city.
The city’s Mardi Gras celebration is one of the most famous in the world.
trivia: New Orleans’ St. Louis Cathedral is the oldest continuously active cathedral in the US.
The city’s annual Jazz & Heritage Festival attracts over 400,000 visitors.

clues: This city is known for its eco-friendliness and craft beer scene.
Home to the famous Powell’s City of Books and Forest Park.
fun_facts: Portland’s Powell’s City of Books is the largest independent bookstore in the world.
The city’s Forest Park is one of the largest urban forests in the US.
trivia: Portland’s annual Rose Festival is one of the oldest and largest in the US.

clues: This city is known for its historic missions and River Walk.

trivia: San Antonio’s Fiesta is one of the largest festivals in the US.

clues: This city is known for its financial industry and NASCAR.
Home to the NASCAR Hall of Fame and Bank of America Stadium.

trivia: Charlotte’s NASCAR Hall of Fame celebrates the history of stock car racing.
The city’s annual Carolina Renaissance Festival is one of the largest in the US.

clues: This city is known for its motorsports and cultural institutions.
Home to the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and the Children’s Museum of Indianapolis.
fun_facts: Indianapolis’s Indianapolis Motor Speedway is home to the famous Indy 500 race.
The city’s Children’s Museum of Indianapolis is the largest children’s museum in the world.
trivia: Indianapolis’s Monument Circle is a historic landmark in the heart of the city.
The city’s annual Indy Jazz Fest attracts top jazz musicians from around the world.

fun_facts: Columbus’s Ohio State University is one of the largest universities in the US.
The city’s Short North Arts District is known for its galleries and restaurants.
trivia: Columbus’s annual ComFest is one of the largest free music festivals in the US.
The city’s Franklin Park Conservatory and Botanical Gardens is a popular attraction.

clues: This city is known for its automotive industry and Motown music.

The city’s Henry Ford Museum is one of the largest indoor-outdoor museums in the US.

The city’s annual Detroit Jazz Festival is the largest free jazz festival in the world.

clues: This city is known for its blues music and barbecue.

clues: This city is known for its historic harbor and seafood.

clues: This city is known for its jazz heritage and barbecue.

The city’s annual Kansas City Renaissance Festival is one of the largest in the US.

clues: This city is known for its breweries and Lake Michigan shoreline.

The city’s annual Summerfest is the world’s largest music festival.

fun_facts: Minneapolis’s Chain of Lakes is a popular spot for outdoor activities.

trivia: Minneapolis’s Guthrie Theater is one of the most renowned regional theaters in the US.
The city’s annual Twin Cities Pride Festival is one of the largest LGBTQ+ events in the US.

clues: This city is known for its beaches and Cuban influence.

The city’s Tampa Riverwalk is a popular spot for dining and entertainment.
